title: Firms mixed up in the Woodford scandal may be sued by savers
text:
Savers who have lost millions of pound could seek to claw back some losses from Neil Woodford

Firms embroiled in the Woodford scandal may be sued, say lawyers.

Savers who have lost millions of pounds could seek to claw back some losses from Neil Woodford, and others who worked with him.

The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA)is probing him for seemingly attempting to dodge rules to protect investors in his Equity Income fund.

To stay within these rules, Woodford listed his stakes in companies held by the fund on the Guernsey stock exchange.

If the FCA decides this breached good practice, it could fine Woodford. David Greene, a partner at Edwin Coe, said: 'If there was a breach of regulations, a claim could arise.'

James Kaufman, at law firm Howard Kennedy, said Link, which oversaw Woodford's management of funds, would be first in the crosshairs.
